titleStmt.title: C 0 Interior Penalty Methods for Fourth Order Elliptic Boundary Value Problems on Polygonal Domains

analytic.title: C 0 Interior Penalty Methods for Fourth Order Elliptic Boundary Value Problems on Polygonal Domains

biblStruct.note: Received August 12, 2003; accepted (in revised form) April 22, 2004

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: C 0 interior penalty methods for fourth order elliptic boundary value problems on polygonal domains are analyzed in this paper. A post-processing procedure that can generate C 1 approximate solutions from the C 0 approximate solutions is presented. New C 0 interior penalty methods based on the techniques involved in the post-processing procedure are introduced. These new methods are applicable to rough right-hand sides.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Let Ω ⊂ R 2 be a bounded polygonal domain. In this paper, we consider the following fourth order model problem:
Find u ∈ H 2 0 (Ω) such that
where
div.formula: a(w, v) = Ω D 2 w : D 2 v + β(x)∇w • ∇v dx ∀ w, v ∈ H 2 (Ω), (1.2) D 2 w : D 2 v = 2 i,j =1
div.p: w x i x j v x i x j , β(x) is a nonnegative C 1 function on Ω, and F ∈ H -2 (Ω) = [H 2 0 (Ω)] . Here and throughout the paper we use the standard notation for the L 2 based Sobolev spaces [1,15,14].

For β = 0, the problem (1.1) is the weak form of the biharmonic problem with homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions. For β > 0, it is a scalar analog of the variational problem for the strain gradient theory in elasticity and plasticity [21,27]. Since the bilinear form a(•, •) is bounded and coercive on H 2 0 (Ω), the variational problem (1.1) has a unique solution u and
div.formula: u H 2 (Ω) C Ω F H -2 (Ω) .
div.p: Note that throughout the paper we use C (with or without subscripts) to denote a generic positive constant that can take different values at different appearances.

Conforming finite element methods for (1.1) involve C 1 finite elements, which are quite complicated even in two dimensions (cf. [3,8,18] and the references therein). For the biharmonic problem an alternative is to use classical nonconforming finite elements [2,23,26]. However, these elements must be modified and hence become more complicated when β = 0 (cf. [25]). Furthermore the construction of higher order nonconforming finite elements for fourth order problems is also far from obvious.

In this paper, we analyze C 0 interior penalty methods (also known as continuous/discontinuous Galerkin methods) for the model problem (1.1). The finite elements we use are just the P k (the space of polynomials of total degree k) Lagrange triangular elements and the quadrilateral elements generated by the Q k (the space of polynomials of degree k in each variable) rectangular elements through bilinear transformations. These are finite elements designed for second order problems and the finite element spaces are subspaces of C 0 ( Ω). The corresponding interior penalty methods satisfy quasi-optimal error estimates for regular triangulations of Ω. The complexity of the lower order C 0 interior penalty methods are comparable to that of the classical nonconforming finite element methods. At the same time the higher order C 0 interior penalty methods, which are useful for capturing smooth solutions, are much simpler than the C 1 finite element methods. We also show that a post-processing procedure can generate C 1 finite element approximate solutions for (1.1) from the approximate solutions obtained by the interior penalty methods. The techniques involved in the post-processing procedure also enable us to introduce new C 0 interior penalty methods that are applicable for F ∈ H -2 (Ω), and these techniques are also important for the convergence analysis of multigrid algorithms and for the design of domain decomposition preconditioners.

The study of interior penalty methods for fourth order problems dates back to the 1970s. A C 0 interior penalty method for the biharmonic problem in two-dimensions was studied in [4]. It was based on the cubic Hermite triangular element and an inconsistent formulation. The error estimate obtained in [4] is sub-optimal due to the inconsistency.

Interior penalty methods for the biharmonic problem for two dimensional smooth domains were also studied in [6]. The formulation there is consistent and is based on discontinuous finite elements, and quasi-optimal error estimates were obtained for smooth solutions. In comparison, the C 0 interior methods in this paper involve fewer degrees of freedom because nodal values are shared on inter-element boundaries. This is of course made possible by the absence of hanging nodes in our approach.

Our work is motivated by the recent paper [20], where consistent C 0 interior penalty methods for plate bending problems using quadrilateral elements were investigated and quasi-optimal error estimates were obtained for smooth solutions. A one dimensional analog of (1.1) was also treated in [20]. (The readers are referred there for a discussion of the numerical performance of these methods.) We extend the analysis of [20] to polygonal domains, where in general the solution does not belong to
div.formula: H 4 (Ω) even if F (v)= Ω f v dx for f ∈ C ∞ ( Ω)
div.p: . Indeed for the model problem (1.1) the shift theorem (cf. [22,17,24,5]) for a polygonal domain in general only holds for some α ∈ (1/2, 1], i.e., the solution u of (1.1) belongs to H 2+α (Ω) whenever F ∈ H -2+α (Ω) and
div.formula: u H 2+α (Ω) C Ω F H -2+α (Ω) .
div.p: (1.4) (In the case of a convex polygon, the estimate (1.4) holds for α = 1.) We shall refer to α as the index of elliptic regularity. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The post-processing and analysis of the C 0 interior penalty methods rely on related C 1 finite elements, which are presented in Section 2, and the connections between triangular C 0 finite elements and their C 1 relatives are explored in Section 3. Triangular C 0 interior penalty methods are then treated in Section 4 and Section 5. Quadrilateral C 0 interior penalty methods are discussed in Section 6, followed by some concluding remarks in Section 7.

div.head: C 0 ELEMENTS AND THEIR C 1 RELATIVES
div.p: In this section we discuss C 1 finite elements that are related to the P k and Q k C 0 -elements. Such elements will play an important role in the post-processing of the solutions obtained by the interior penalty methods.

Let (K, P 1 , N 1 ) and (K, P 2 , N 2 ) be two finite elements [14,15] on the same domain K, where P j is the space of shape functions and N j is the set of nodal variables (degrees of freedom). We say that these elements are relatives if P 1 ⊆ P 2 and N 1 ⊆ N 2 , and we use the notation (K, P 1 , N 1 ) (K, P 2 , N 2 ) to represent such a relation. The concept of relatives is useful for the construction of embedding maps from nonconforming finite element spaces to Sobolev spaces that have natural left inverses (cf. [10,12]).

For example, the P 5 Argyris element [3] is a C 1 relative of the P 1 Lagrange element and the Q 3 Bogner-Fox-Schmit [8] element is a relative of the Q 1 tensor product element. These elements are depicted in Fig. 1 and Fig. 2, where we use the solid dot • to denote the pointwise evaluation of the shape functions, the small circle e (resp. larger circle g ) to denote the pointwise evaluations of all the first (resp. second) order derivatives of the shape functions, the arrow ↑ to denote the pointwise evaluation of the normal derivative, and the to denote the pointwise evaluation of the mixed second order derivative. For the treatment of the fourth order problem (1.1) we need to consider C 1 relatives for the P k and Q k elements where k 2.

For k 2, the triangular P k Lagrange element has a C 1 relative whose shape functions are the polynomials in P k+4 and whose nodal variables consist of the pointwise evaluations of the shape functions at the nodes of the P k Lagrange element, the pointwise evaluations of first and second order derivatives of the shape functions at the vertices of the triangle, the evaluations of the normal derivatives at k interior points on each edge, and (k -1)k/2 additional interior nodal variables that uniquely
div.formula: . 2. Q 1 C 0 -element and Q 3 C 1 -element.
div.p: determine polynomials in P k-2 . These C 1 elements are variants of the elements in the TUBA family introduced by Argyris et al. in [3]. The cases of k = 2, 3 and 4 are depicted in Figs. 345. We shall also refer to these elements as Argyris elements.

For k 2, the Q k tensor product element has a C 1 relative whose shape functions are the polynomials in Q k+2 and whose nodal variables consist of the pointwise evaluations of the shape functions at the nodes of the Q k tensor product element, the pointwise evaluations of the first order derivatives and the mixed second order derivative at the vertices and the evaluations of the normal derivatives at k -1 interior nodes on each edge. These C 1 elements are generalizations of the Bogner-Fox-Schmit element introduced in [8]. The cases of k = 2 and 3 are depicted in Fig. 6 Fig. 3. P 2 C 0 -element and P 6 C 1 -element. and Fig. 7. We shall also refer to these elements as Bogner-Fox-Schmit elements.

div.head: TRIANGULAR C 0 INTERIOR PENALTY METHODS
div.p: In this section we formulate C 0 interior penalty methods for (1.1) using the Lagrange finite element space V h ⊂ H 1 0 (Ω). We begin by deriving an identity involving the solution u of (1.1) and functions from V h . This identity is well known in the case where u h is smooth [6,20], but in the case where Ω is a polygonal domain it requires further justification.
Let G be a bounded open set with a piecewise smooth boundary. For w, v ∈ C ∞ ( Ḡ), integration by parts yields the following formulas:
div.formula: G (∆ 2 w)v dx = ∂G ∂(∆w) ∂n v ds - G ∇(∆w) • ∇v dx = ∂G ∂(∆w) ∂n v ds - 2 i=1 G ∇ • ∇w x i v x i dx = ∂G ∂(∆w) ∂n v ds - ∂G ∂ ∂n ∇w • ∇v ds + G D 2 w : D 2 v dx, (4.1)
G [∇ • β(x)∇w)]v dx = - ∂G β(x) ∂w ∂n v ds + G β(x)∇w • ∇v dx. (4.2)
div.p: Hence, for w ∈ C ∞ ( Ω) and v ∈ V h , we obtain, by summing up (4.1) and (4.2) over all the triangles in T h and using the fact that the tangential derivative of v is continuous on the inter-element boundaries and vanishes on ∂Ω,

div.head: QUADRILATERAL C 0 INTERIOR PENALTY METHODS
div.p: In this section we outline the extension of the results in Sections 3-5 to quadrilateral elements.

Let T h be a triangulation of Ω consisting of convex quadrilaterals. For any quadrilateral Q ∈ T h , we define a finite element (Q, P Q , N Q ) as follows. Let B Q : S -→ Q be a bilinear diffeomorphism, where S = [-1, 1] 2 is the reference square. For k 2, the space of shape functions on Q is defined to be
div.formula: P Q = {v ∈ C ∞ ( Q) : v • B Q ∈ Q k }
div.p: and the set N Q of nodal variables consists of pointwise evaluations of the shape functions at the nodes of Q corresponding to the nodes in S for the Q k element. (The case of k = 2 is depicted in Fig. 9.) The finite element spaces V h for the C 0 interior penalty methods are then defined by
div.formula: V h = {v ∈ H 1 0 (Ω) : v Q = v Q ∈ P Q ∀ Q ∈ T h }.(6.1)
div.p: Since P k ⊂ P Q , the interpolation error estimates (3.16)-(3.20) remain valid for the quadrilateral finite element space V h . The derivation of (4.9) and Lemmas 6 and 7 in Section 4 applies to the quadrilateral finite element space V h without change, where the shape regularity of T h can be described in terms of the minimum angle of the simplicial triangulation Th obtained by adding the diagonals of the quadrilaterals in T h . We can therefore formulate a consistent and well-posed interior penalty method by (4.15). Since the abstract estimate (5.1) and the estimates (5.3) and (5.9) hold for V h , we obtain all the results for uu h (with necessary obvious modifications in notation) in Theorem 1, Theorem 3, Theorem 5 and Corollary 2.

Next, we introduce a C 1 relative for the C 0 element (Q, P Q , N Q ). In the case of a rectangular element, we can take the Q k+2 Bogner-Fox-Schmit finite element to be its C 1 relative (cf. Figs. 6 and7). In the case of a general convex quadrilateral, we need to consider variants of higher order Bogner-Fox-Schmit elements. First, we define these variants on the reference square S.

Let the space of shape functions be Q for 6 and the set of nodal variables consists of (i) evaluations of the shape functions up to second order derivatives at the four vertices of S, (ii) evaluations of the normal derivatives of the shape functions at -3 interior points on each edge of S, (iii) evaluations of the shape functions at -5 interior points on each edge of S, (iv) evaluations of the shape functions at ( -3) 2 interior points of S that uniquely determine the polynomials in Q -4 .

It is easy to check that the ( + 1) 2 nodal variables uniquely determine the functions in Q , and we will denote this element by (S, Q , N ). The element (S, Q 6 , N 6 ) is depicted in the first figure of Fig. 10. Let Q ∈ T h be a convex quadrilateral and B Q : S -→ Q be a bilinear diffeomorphism. We are now ready to define a C 1 element (Q, PQ , ÑQ ) as follows. For k 2, we define the space PQ of shape functions by The set ÑQ of nodal variables consist of (i) the evaluations of the shape functions up to second order derivatives at the four vertices of Q, (ii) the evaluations of the normal derivatives of the shape functions at k interior points on each edge of Q, (iii) the evaluations of the shape functions at (k -1) interior points on each edge of Q, (iv) the evaluations of the shape functions at (k + 1) 2 interior points of Q corresponding to interior nodes in S that uniquely determine the functions in Q k .
div.formula: PQ = {v ∈ C ∞ ( Q) : v • B Q ∈ Q
div.p: The case of k = 2 is depicted in the second figure of Fig. 10.

To see that (Q, PQ , ÑQ ) is indeed a finite element, we must demonstrate that there is a unique shape function in PQ corresponding to a set of arbitrarily assigned values of the nodal variables in ÑQ Therefore it remains to check that the values of the normal derivatives of v at the (k + 1) interior points on an edge of S are also uniquely determined if the normal derivatives of v are given at k interior points of the corresponding edge of Q. Below we will demonstrate this for the edge ê = {(1, s) : -1 s 1} of S.
div.formula: . Let v ∈ Q k+4 and v ∈ C ∞ ( Q) be related by the equation v = v • B Q . (6
div.p: Let the coordinates on Q be denoted by (ξ 1 , ξ 2 ). Then
where ξ 1 and ξ 2 are bilinear functions in (x 1 , x 2 ). We have, by (6.2), (6.3) and the chain rule,

where t = (a 1 , a 2 ) is a unit tangent vector of the edge of Q corresponding to ê, v t (s) is the derivative of v at the point B Q (1, s) in the direction of t and v n is the derivative of v at the point B Q (1, s) in the direction of n = (a 2 , -a 1 ). Note that v t (s) and v n (s) are both polynomials in s of degree k + 3, and the functions a 1 (∂ξ 1 /∂x 1 ) + a 2 (∂ξ 2 /∂x 1 ) and a 2 (∂ξ 1 /∂x 1 )a 1 (∂ξ 2 /∂x 1 ) are polynomials in s of degree 1 on ê. Moreover, v(s) = v(B Q (1, s)) is a polynomial of degree k + 4 uniquely determined by its derivatives up to second order at ±1 and its values at (k -1) points in the open interval (-1, 1), and the polynomial v n (s) of degree k + 3 is uniquely determined by its derivatives up to first order at ±1 and its values at k points in the open interval (-1, 1). Therefore the relation (6.4) allows us to determine (∂ v/∂x 1 )(1, s) uniquely as a polynomial of degree k + 4 and to uniquely assign its values at the k + 1 nodes in the open interval (-1, 1).

Note that if two quadrilaterals Q 1 and Q 2 in T h share a common edge e and two shape functions v 1 ∈ PQ 1 and v 2 ∈ PQ 2 share common nodal values along e, then v 1 and v 2 match up to the first order derivatives at e. This is due to the fact that (i) v 1 and v 2 are both polynomials of degree k + 4 along e and they agree at k -1 interior points of e and up to the second order derivatives at the endpoints of e, (ii) (∂v 1 /∂n) and (∂v 2 /∂n) are both polynomials of degree k + 3 along e and they agree at k interior points of e and up to the first order derivatives at the endpoints of e. Therefore (Q, PQ , ÑQ ) is a C 1 element and it is clear that (Q, P Q , N Q ) (Q, PQ , ÑQ ) (cf. the elements depicted in Figs. 9 and 10) if the nodes of ÑQ are properly placed.
We now piece the finite elements (Q, PQ , PQ ) together to form the C 1 finite element space
div.formula: W h = {w ∈ H 2 0 (Ω) : w Q = w Q ∈ PQ ∀ Q ∈ T h }. (6.5)
div.p: The construction of the enriching operator E h : V h -→ W h follows the same steps as in Section 3. First we define Ẽh on the C 0 quadrilateral finite element space without boundary conditions by the formula (3.2), and then we define E h v for v ∈ V h by modifying the nodal values of Ẽh v on ∂Ω. The proofs of Lemmas 1-4 remain valid and the relation (3.30) still holds.

We can now formulate an interior penalty method for the quadrilateral C 0 finite element space by (4.17) and post-process the solutions obtained by the interior penalty methods using the operator E h . The results for u -E h u h , uu h and u -E h u h (with necessary obvious modifications in notation) in Theorems 2-6 and Corollary 2 follow by the same arguments.

div.head: CONCLUDING REMARKS
div.p: We have shown that the C 0 interior penalty method of [20] can be extended to polygonal domains and nonsmooth solutions. By constructing a map E h from the C 0 finite element space to a related C 1 finite element space, we have been able to formulate interior penalty methods that are applicable to problems with rough right-hand sides and also generate C 1 approximate solutions by a post-processing procedure. We note that the error estimates in • H 2-α (Ω) and Lemma 9 are also useful for the convergence analysis of multigrid methods [15].

The results in Theorems 1 and 2 indicate that triangular and quadrilateral elements containing P 3 are relevant for the efficient solution of (4.15) when F ∈ L 2 (Ω). In the case where F belongs to higher order Sobolev spaces and the coefficient function β is smoother than C 1 , the solution u of (1.1) is more regular away from the vertices of Ω and higher order C 0 elements may be used. We note that there are multigrid methods (cf. [11]) that can take advantage of the decomposition (4.4) and zero in on the smooth part of u. Higher order C 0 interior penalty methods are also relevant for such multigrid algorithms. Hence in these situations the C 0 interior penalty methods have advantages over the classical nonconforming finite element methods which are only of low order.

The approach developed in this paper can also be applied to general boundary conditions and interface problems. For such problems the index α of elliptic regularity can be very close to 0 and consequently V h ⊂ H -2+α (Ω). But the estimates for u -E h u h H 2-α (Ω) and u -E h u h H 2-α (Ω) are still meaningful. Therefore the operator E h plays an essential role in extracting lower order error estimates in these situations. The details will be carried out elsewhere.

Since the finite element spaces are the ones designed for second order problems, the C 0 interior penalty methods developed in this paper can also be applied to certain singular perturbation problems for fourth order elliptic equations [25].

The generalization of the results to three dimensions and/or the systems of partial differential equations for the strain-gradient theory of elasticity and plasticity [21,27] will require a careful analysis of the singularities of the solutions involved and a careful study of C 1 elements in three dimensions. It will be pursued in the future.
